qas.question: What year was the Standard Output Sensitivity technique introduced?
What does the Standard Output Sensitivity technique apply to?
What is the output level measured in?

answers.text: the sRGB output from the camera

qas.question: With what type of metering can the Standard Output Sensitivity not be used?
With what standard is the automatic exposure control system calibrated?
What technique was removed in the 2006 standards?
When exposure is not automatically controlled, what is the gray set at?
How are files in raw measured?
Multi-zone metering uses what ISO calibration?
When was the SOS technique applied to raw images?

context: <b5_0>The Standard Output Sensitivity (SOS)<b5_0/> technique, also new in the <a0_0><b9_0>2006<b9_0/><a0_0/> version of the standard, effectively specifies that the average level in the sRGB image must be <b6_0><b7_0>18%<b6_0/> gray plus or minus 1/3 stop<b7_0/> when the exposure is controlled by an automatic exposure control system calibrated per <a4_0>ISO <b8_0>2721<b8_0/><a4_0/> and set to the EI with no exposure compensation. Because the output level is measured in <a2_0>the sRGB output from the camera<a2_0/>, it is only applicable to <a1_0>sRGB images—typically JPEG<a1_0/>—and not to output files in raw image format. It is not applicable when <a3_0>multi-zone metering<a3_0/> is used.
